title: Ask A Policeman
descriptions:
Set in the sleepy English village of Turnbotham Round, Ask a Policeman (1939) is a classic British comedy that follows the bumbling exploits of Sergeant Samuel Dudfoot and his two equally inept constables, Albert Brown and Dennis Gowler. For years, the trio has proudly reported no crime in their parish—a statistic that keeps their workload light but puts their jobs in jeopardy when the Chief Constable arrives to warn them that a total absence of crime suggests negligence rather than efficiency. Faced with the threat of being disbanded, the officers hatch a plan: they will manufacture a crime wave to prove their worth.

Their efforts begin with petty mischief staged to look like real offences, but things quickly spiral into farce. In trying to invent culprits, they stumble upon whispers of a genuine local legend: the phantom of Black Shuck Lane, a spectral coach and ghostly rider said to haunt the moors near a ruined mansion. Dudfoot seizes on the legend as a perfect cover for their invented crimes, hoping to pin mysterious goings-on on the supernatural while quietly “solving” them. But as they bumble through séances, stakeouts, and midnight patrols, they unwittingly uncover clues pointing to real criminal activity.

The trio’s staged incidents are soon eclipsed by a rash of cleverly organized smuggling operations centered around the old mansion and its coastal caves. Strange lights at night, hoofbeats with no horse in sight, and the echo of wheels on the lane add to the eerie atmosphere. Dudfoot and his men, terrified yet determined, chase what they believe are their own fictions only to collide with a well-run gang using the ghost story as camouflage. Their comedic incompetence leads to a series of misunderstandings, including Dudfoot nearly arresting himself and the constables becoming convinced they’ve encountered actual apparitions.

Romance and village life thread through the chaos: local innkeepers share lore, a young woman’s connection to the mansion provides crucial leads, and the policemen’s attempts at dignity repeatedly collapse into slapstick—rickety bicycles, stuck boots in the marsh, and ill-timed disguises. A pivotal sequence sees the trio follow the “phantom coach” into the fog, where shadowy figures and hidden trapdoors reveal the practical mechanics behind the haunting. What seemed spectral proves to be stagecraft: false wheels, lantern signals, muffled hooves, and a concealed route for contraband.

When the Chief Constable returns to assess their progress, Dudfoot blusters through a demonstration that accidentally exposes the smugglers’ pipeline. A chase ensues across moor and shoreline, with Dudfoot clinging to the coach, Brown and Gowler pedaling furiously, and the gang scrambling to scuttle evidence in sea caves. Their comic ineptitude turns decisive at last: a bungled barricade becomes a perfect trap, and a misread signal summons allies instead of accomplices. The smugglers are unmasked, the “ghost” debunked, and the law—almost in spite of itself—prevails.

In the aftermath, Dudfoot tries to present the case as the fruit of meticulous policing, but his tall tale is punctured by the very villagers who helped, and by his constables’ cheerful honesty. Yet their success is undeniable: a real criminal ring has been captured, the phantom laid to rest, and Turnbotham Round can claim a genuine crime solved at last. The Chief Constable, half-amused and half-exasperated, grants them a reprieve. Dudfoot, basking in unexpected glory, vows to maintain order—though the final gags suggest his methods will never be less than chaotic.

Ask a Policeman blends spooky atmosphere with broad slapstick and sharp wordplay, anchored by the endearingly hapless Dudfoot and his men. The film satirizes small-town complacency and the foibles of authority while delivering a playful mystery: what begins as a fabricated crime spree transforms into a real investigation, with a ghost story unmasked as human mischief. In classic fashion, the trio’s blunders become their brilliance, turning accidental discovery into heroic result and restoring peace to a village that, it turns out, was never as quiet as it seemed.
